title: Teenager Curtis Jones scores winning shootout pen after Liverpool and Arsenal's ten-goal Carabao classic
text:
As the champions of Europe, and the leaders of the Premier League, Liverpool are supposed to be above such preoccupations as the Carabao Cup but when you have shared ten goals over 90 crazy minutes of a wonderful absurdity of a match then why not just go for it?

Their winning penalty in the shoot-out was dispatched by Curtis Jones, one of five teenagers who figured for Jurgen Klopp, a manager whose starting line-up and bench might have suggested to the more conspiratorially-minded that he fancied a fourth round exit.

Instead they just kept on coming back from one goal up to 3-1 down, all the way back to 4-4 and then 5-5 when for the second time in the second half, Divock Origi equalised, his second in time added on at the end.

You might even say that Klopp won this tie, and a place in the quarter-finals, by accident. No such luck for the beleaguered Arsenal manager Unai Emery, who saw all his team’s penalties in the shoot-out scored apart from that fourth taken by Dani Ceballos and saved by Caoimhin Kelleher.

It was a marvellous game but that, one suspects, will be scant comfort to a manager who cannot catch a break. Goals everywhere, the famous 4-4 Premier League scoreline between these two clubs from April 2009 was equalled before the hour and there was more to come, including a brilliant fifth for Arsenal dispatched by 20-year-old Joe Willock that might have decided the game.
description: As the champions of Europe, and the leaders of the Premier League, Liverpool are supposed to be above such preoccupations as the Carabao Cup but when you have shared ten goals over 90 crazy minutes of a wonderful absurdity of a match then why not just go for it?
